transcript.text: You should not use competitive intelligence that’s improperly obtained. Do you know the difference? Click on each heading to check your understanding.

contentText.text: So how can you make sure that certain information is safe to use? Before accepting, using, or sharing any information about competitors or the market, ask yourself:

instructionText.text: Select each heading. To read the next, click the X to close the text box.
Click on Next (bottom right arrow) to continue.

revealCallOut.buttonText: Is this information available to the public?

popText.text: We can always use publicly available information about our competitors – and there is a surprising amount available.

You can check:
  • filings with government agencies
  • public speeches by company executives
  • annual reports
  • analyst reports
  • news stories, press releases and trade journal articles
  • trade show exhibits
  • job postings
  • published patent and trademark applications
If you use sources like these, make sure to keep a record as proof that the information was obtained properly.

If so, we cannot use it. This includes information that:
  • the company it belongs to would consider confidential
  • belongs to a former employer
  • was gathered through deception, such as pretending to be someone else
  • was obtained illegally, such as by trespassing or gaining access to another company’s computer networks
  • we bribed someone to obtain
